claim.text: a ground-source system delivering 35°C water to a radiant floor operates at a COP of 4 or higher
claim.claim: Ground-source heat pump delivering 35°C water to radiant floor achieves COP of 4 or higher

results.summary: This claim aligns with well-established HVAC engineering principles and documented performance data for ground-source heat pumps operating at low supply temperatures.
results.detail: Ground-source heat pumps (GSHPs) typically achieve COP values of 3.5-5.0 under optimal conditions. The COP is highly dependent on the temperature lift (difference between source and delivery temperature). Radiant floor systems operating at 35°C (95°F) represent a low-temperature application, which minimizes the temperature lift and maximizes COP. With ground temperatures typically 10-15°C and delivery at 35°C, the modest temperature lift of 20-25°C readily supports COP values of 4 or higher. This is consistent with data from DOE, ASHRAE, and manufacturer specifications.

claim.text: PEX tubing (typically 16mm or 20mm diameter) is laid in serpentine loops at 150–300mm spacing
claim.claim: Standard PEX tubing for radiant floors is 16mm or 20mm diameter at 150–300mm spacing

results.summary: The PEX tubing diameter and spacing specifications align with industry standards for radiant floor heating systems.
results.detail: Standard PEX tubing for radiant floor heating commonly uses 1/2 inch (approximately 12.7mm), 5/8 inch (approximately 16mm), and 3/4 inch (approximately 19mm/20mm) diameters. The 16mm and 20mm specifications mentioned correspond closely to standard imperial sizes used in North America and metric standards used in Europe. Tube spacing of 150-300mm (6-12 inches) is the typical range, with closer spacing providing more heat output. Industry guidelines from manufacturers like Uponor, Rehau, and Watts recommend these specifications.

claim.text: Supply water temperature should not exceed 40°C when connected to a heat pump system; target floor surface temperature of 24–28°C in occupied areas
claim.claim: Heat pump radiant floor systems should use supply water temperature not exceeding 40°C with target floor surface temperature of 24–28°C

results.summary: The claimed temperatures align with established industry standards and engineering guidelines for heat pump radiant floor systems.
results.detail: Industry standards (including ISO 7730 and ASHRAE guidelines) specify maximum floor surface temperatures of 29°C for occupied areas for comfort, with 24-28°C being the typical operational target range. Supply water temperatures of 35-45°C are standard for low-temperature radiant systems designed for heat pump compatibility, with 40°C being a commonly cited maximum for optimal heat pump efficiency (COP). These figures are consistent with guidance from manufacturers like Uponor, Rehau, and others.
sources: ASHRAE Handbook - HVAC Systems and Equipment

claim.claim: Radiant floor surface temperature should not exceed 29°C

results.summary: The 29°C maximum floor surface temperature is a widely recognized standard in radiant heating design based on thermal comfort research.
results.detail: This figure comes from thermal comfort standards including ISO 7730 and ASHRAE guidelines, which recommend a maximum floor surface temperature of 29°C (approximately 84°F) for occupied spaces to prevent thermal discomfort from excessive foot warmth. The limit is based on research into human thermal comfort and has been adopted in building codes and engineering standards internationally. Higher temperatures (up to 35°C) are sometimes permitted in peripheral zones or bathrooms.
sources: ASHRAE Handbook - HVAC Systems and Equipment
